content.raw:
The bullet version of the test fails on utopic, which has a single precision version of bullet, while trusty has a library compiled with double precision.

There's about 7 other tests with similar failures. I've been meaning to relax the expectations for single precision bullet, but haven't gotten to it.

See issue: #848
content.html:
The bullet version of the test fails on utopic, which has a single precision version of bullet, while trusty has a library compiled with double precision.

There's about 7 other tests with similar failures. I've been meaning to relax the expectations for single precision bullet, but haven't gotten to it.

See issue: #848

content.raw:
This test has been [failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_6.0-devel-utopic-amd64/21/testReport/%28root%29/PhysicsEngines_AltimeterSensor_TEST/LinearAltimeterSensorCheck_1/) sometimes, should we add some tolerance?

~~~
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-gazebo_6.0-devel-utopic-amd64/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/AltimeterSensor_TEST.cc:141
Value of: physics->GetGravity().z * (physics->GetMaxStepSize()*steps)
  Actual: -0.098000000000000004
Expected: altSensor->VerticalVelocity()
Which is: -0.098000012338161469
~~~

update.description: Helping Andrew out. This is a redo of pull request #1751.
update.title: Altimeter sensor (Redo of pull request #1751)

content.raw:
Here are some answers:

1. The center of the link does have some linear velocity. The sensor at the end of the link has only angular velocity. The angular velocity of the link should match the angular velocity of the sensor. 
2. We can run for more than one step, but it doesn't really buy us much. The test will work with 10, 20, 100, time steps.
3. In this case `avel.Sum` and `avel.X` should be the same. I chose `avel.Sum` so that the test would fail if for some reason additional angular velocity existed on other axes.
4. We could use either WorldAngularVel or RelativeAngularVel. You can run the test with `GetWorldAngularVel`, and it will still work.
content.html:
Here are some answers:

  1. The center of the link does have some linear velocity. The sensor at the end of the link has only angular velocity. The angular velocity of the link should match the angular velocity of the sensor.
  2. We can run for more than one step, but it doesn't really buy us much. The test will work with 10, 20, 100, time steps.
  3. In this case avel.Sum and avel.X should be the same. I chose avel.Sum so that the test would fail if for some reason additional angular velocity existed on other axes.
  4. We could use either WorldAngularVel or RelativeAngularVel. You can run the test with GetWorldAngularVel, and it will still work.

content.raw: I left a few comments in the test but they're not blockers for me. Approving!
content.html: I left a few comments in the test but they're not blockers for me. Approving!
e2f8291
e2f8291
e2f8291

content.raw:
The test passes and now I get why, sorry for all the noise and confusion regarding the angular velocity.

For completeness, I'll just make a few comments which came to me while I was reviewing but it might be more noise.

1. As I understood it, the intent of this test was to show the altimeter in action when the parent link has only angular velocity, but the way the test world was setup, the link origin is 5m away from the rotation center so it has linear velocity - which is different from the altimeter's velocity but it isn't zero.

1. The velocity check below is done for only one world step, but the test could be easily extended to loop through a few steps and check that the velocity evolves correctly. Not sure if it's worth the extra test time perhaps...

1. I'm not sure why `avel.Sum()` was taken instead of `avel.X()` - I'm not sure this would work for rotations on non canonical angles.

1. If the altimeter measures the vertical velocity in the world frame, shouldn't we take `GetWorldAngularVel` instead of `GetRelativeAngularVel`?
content.html:
The test passes and now I get why, sorry for all the noise and confusion regarding the angular velocity.

For completeness, I'll just make a few comments which came to me while I was reviewing but it might be more noise.

  1. As I understood it, the intent of this test was to show the altimeter in action when the parent link has only angular velocity, but the way the test world was setup, the link origin is 5m away from the rotation center so it has linear velocity - which is different from the altimeter's velocity but it isn't zero.

  2. The velocity check below is done for only one world step, but the test could be easily extended to loop through a few steps and check that the velocity evolves correctly. Not sure if it's worth the extra test time perhaps...

  3. I'm not sure why avel.Sum() was taken instead of avel.X() - I'm not sure this would work for rotations on non canonical angles.

  4. If the altimeter measures the vertical velocity in the world frame, shouldn't we take GetWorldAngularVel instead of GetRelativeAngularVel?

update.description: Helping Andrew out. This is a redo of pull request #1751.
update.title: Altimeter sensor (Redo of pull request #1751)

content.raw: That is true, but not all the test use this function.
content.html: That is true, but not all the test use this function.

content.raw:
Here are the tests:

1. Linear: The sensor drops straight down, there is no joint and no angular component.
2. Angular: The sensor is at one end of a 10m long bar. The other end of the bar is connected to the world with a revolute joint. Gravity causes the bar to rotate down, and the sensor measures this velocity.
3. Linear + Angular: The same bar in #2 now has a prismatic component that causes the bar to both linearly drop and rotate. 

Is there another test you'd like to see?
content.html:
Here are the tests:

  1. Linear: The sensor drops straight down, there is no joint and no angular component.
  2. Angular: The sensor is at one end of a 10m long bar. The other end of the bar is connected to the world with a revolute joint. Gravity causes the bar to rotate down, and the sensor measures this velocity.
  3. Linear + Angular: The same bar in #2 now has a prismatic component that causes the bar to both linearly drop and rotate.

Is there another test you'd like to see?

content.raw:
If I understand correctly, all the examples in the tests have `sensor pose == parent pose`, because that's the [default](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=sensor#sensor_pose) and nothing is being set in the SDF, correct? (I commented on ServerFixture line 944).

But if the pose is not zero, imagine a ball falling and rotating with the sensor on its surface. The linear velocity of the sensor on the surface is different from the velocity of the ball (its center).


![vel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3576582185-vel.gif)
content.html:
If I understand correctly, all the examples in the tests have sensor pose == parent pose, because that's the default and nothing is being set in the SDF, correct? (I commented on ServerFixture line 944).

But if the pose is not zero, imagine a ball falling and rotating with the sensor on its surface. The linear velocity of the sensor on the surface is different from the velocity of the ball (its center).

content.raw: All sensors are spawned with the default zero pose, so they coincide with the parent.
content.html: All sensors are spawned with the default zero pose, so they coincide with the parent.

Same question as in the previous pull request, since there's an offset between the parent and the sensor poses, don't we need to take the parent's angular velocity into account here? Something like:

ignition::math::Vector3d parentLinVel =
    this->dataPtr->parentLink->GetWorldLinearVel(this->pose.pos).Ign();

ignition::math::Vector3d parentAngVel =
    this->dataPtr->parentLink->GetWorldAngularVel(this->pose.pos).Ign();

ignition::math::Vector3d sensorLinVel =
    parentLinVel + parentAngVel * this->pose.Ign().Length();
